questions.text: A full-term baby was born 14 hours ago. As the pediatrician on duty, you are called to assess the newborn for a routine check-up. She asks for clarification on what is considered the normal time frame for a newborn to pass urine and meconium. What would be the appropriate response?

options.label: A
options.text: Urine within 24 hours and meconium within 48 hours

options.label: B
options.text: Urine within 12 hours and meconium within 24 hours

options.label: C
options.text: Urine within 24 hours and meconium within 12 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Urine within 48 hours and meconium within 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: A. Urine within 24 hours and meconium within 48 hours
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ A healthy, full-term newborn is expected to pass urine within 24 hours and meconium within 48 hours after birth. Delays beyond these time frames may indicate underlying pathologies and require medical evaluation.
  • ➤ A healthy, full-term newborn is expected to pass urine within 24 hours and meconium within 48 hours after birth.
  • ➤ Delays beyond these time frames may indicate underlying pathologies and require medical evaluation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, who delivered her first child 3 months ago, presents with progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in her legs. options.label: B

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a diagnosis of exclusion characterized by heart failure in the peripartum period with no identifiable cause. Elevated BNP, reduced ejection fraction, and the timing of symptoms are crucial for diagnosis. Early recognition and management are vital to improving outcomes.
  • ➤ Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a diagnosis of exclusion characterized by heart failure in the peripartum period with no identifiable cause.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of yellowing of the skin and eyes. He denies other symptoms and recalls a similar episode three years ago. Recently, he has noticed dark urine. Laboratory tests reveal a serum bilirubin level of 4.6 mg/dL, predominantly conjugated. Serum AST and ALT levels are within normal limits. A liver biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dubin-Johnson syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive condition characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to impaired hepatic excretion of conjugated bilirubin. Liver biopsy reveals darkly pigmented granules in hepatocytes, a hallmark of the condition.
  • ➤ Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive condition characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to impaired hepatic excretion of conjugated bilirubin. Liver biopsy reveals darkly pigmented granules in hepatocytes, a hallmark of the condition.

Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A clinical trial is conducted to assess the effectiveness of a new antihypertensive medication in reducing blood pressure. questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ generalized

questions.text: A 45-year-old male from a rural region presents with a hypopigmented skin lesion on his back. Educational Objective:

  • ➤ In endemic regions, post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) should be suspected in patients presenting with hypopigmented skin lesions, particularly if there is a history of prior visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: In the context of cancer metastasis, which of the following statements regarding the role of adhesion molecules is accurate? Statement A: E-cadherin downregulation is often observed in tumor cells, allowing them to detach from primary tumors and invade surrounding tissues. Statement B : Integrins play a crucial role in mediating the attachment of circulating tumor cells to endothelial cells in distant organs, facilitating metastatic spread.

options.label: A
options.text: Statement A is correct, and Statement B is incorrect.

options.label: B
options.text: Statement A is incorrect, and Statement B is correct.

options.label: C
options.text: Both Statement A and Statement B are correct.

options.label: D
options.text: Both Statement A and Statement B are incorrect.

questions.correct_answer: C. Both Statement A and Statement B are correct.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cancer metastasis, E-cadherin downregulation facilitates tumor cell detachment from the primary tumor, while integrins mediate the adhesion of circulating tumor cells to endothelial cells in distant organs, enabling metastatic spread. Both mechanisms are critical in the metastatic cascade.
  • ➤ In cancer metastasis, E-cadherin downregulation facilitates tumor cell detachment from the primary tumor, while integrins mediate the adhesion of circulating tumor cells to endothelial cells in distant organs, enabling metastatic spread.
  • ➤ Both mechanisms are critical in the metastatic cascade.

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria are non-sporing anaerobes. Select the correct combination of bacteria that fall into this category. 1. Peptostreptococcus 2. Propionibacterium 3. Clostridium 4. Anthrax 5. Bacteroides

questions.text: A 3-month-old girl is developing cataracts. Other than not having a social smile or being able to track objects visually, all other aspects of the girl’s examination are normal. Tests on the baby’s urine are positive for reducing sugar but negative for glucose. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this girl?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Galactokinase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The 3-month-old girl presents with cataracts and a positive test for reducing sugars in the urine, but negative for glucose. These findings suggest a metabolic disorder involving galactose. The deficiency of galactokinase, an enzyme responsible for the phosphorylation of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate, leads to the accumulation of galactose in the blood (galactosemia) and urine (galactosuria).
  • • In the lens of the eye, accumulated galactose is converted to galactitol, a sugar alcohol, by the enzyme aldose reductase. Galactitol causes osmotic changes in the lens, leading to water retention and cataract formation. The absence of other systemic findings such as liver damage or neurologic effects, which are associated with other disorders of galactose metabolism, points to an isolated galactokinase deficiency.
  • • Thus, the girl's clinical and biochemical presentation is most consistent with galactokinase deficiency.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Aldolase B: Aldolase B is involved in the metabolism of fructose. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to hereditary fructose intolerance, a severe disorder characterized by hypoglycemia, vomiting, failure to thrive, and liver and kidney damage upon fructose ingestion. Cataracts are not typically seen in this condition. Since the presentation in this case is related to galactose metabolism rather than fructose metabolism, aldolase B deficiency is not the correct answer.
  • • Option A. Aldolase B:
  • • Option B. Fructokinase: Fructokinase deficiency causes essential fructosuria, a benign condition in which fructose is excreted in the urine due to the inability to phosphorylate fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. This condition does not cause systemic effects, cataracts, or urine findings as described in this case. Thus, fructokinase deficiency is not relevant to the girl's clinical presentation.
  • • Option B. Fructokinase:
  • • Option D. Galactose 1-phosphate uridylyl transferase (GALT): Deficiency of GALT results in classic galactosemia, a severe condition characterized by cataracts, hepatomegaly, liver dysfunction, and neurologic effects such as developmental delay and seizures. The absence of systemic effects such as liver damage or neurologic symptoms in this child makes GALT deficiency less likely. Additionally, classic galactosemia typically presents earlier in infancy with more severe systemic involvement.
  • • Option D. Galactose 1-phosphate uridylyl transferase (GALT):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Galactokinase deficiency leads to galactose accumulation, which is converted to galactitol in the lens by aldose reductase, causing cataracts.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient undergoes middle ear surgery. Following the procedure, the patient develops lagophthalmos. Examination reveals an impairment of facial muscle function. Which of the following cranial nerves is most likely injured during the surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cranial nerve VII

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) innervates the muscles responsible for facial expressions, including the orbicularis oculi muscle, which facilitates eyelid closure. Injury to this nerve can result in facial muscle paralysis and lagophthalmos, the inability to fully close the eyelids. During middle ear surgery, the facial nerve is particularly susceptible to damage due to its anatomical course through the temporal bone and proximity to the middle ear structures. Such injury can lead to impaired function of facial muscles, manifesting as difficulty in closing the eye completely on the affected side.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Cranial nerve V (Trigeminal nerve): The trigeminal nerve is primarily responsible for facial sensation and motor functions related to mastication. While it innervates muscles such as the masseter and temporalis, it does not control the muscles involved in eyelid closure. Therefore, injury to this nerve would not typically result in lagophthalmos.
  • • Option B. Cranial nerve V (Trigeminal nerve):
  • • Option C. Cranial nerve VI (Abducens nerve): The abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye. Damage to this nerve leads to an inability to move the eye laterally, causing horizontal diplopia, but does not affect eyelid closure.
  • • Option C. Cranial nerve VI (Abducens nerve):
  • • Option D. Cranial nerve IV (Trochlear nerve): The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, which controls downward and inward eye movements. Injury to this nerve results in vertical diplopia, particularly noticeable when looking downwards, but does not impact the muscles responsible for eyelid closure.
  • • Option D. Cranial nerve IV (Trochlear nerve):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Injury to the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) during middle ear surgery can lead to facial muscle paralysis and lagophthalmos due to its role in innervating the muscles responsible for eyelid closure.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the legal doctrine of Volenti non fit injuria?

options.label: A
options.text: A patient can recover damages even if they voluntarily accepted the risk of harm, provided the injury was due to the doctor’s negligence.

options.label: B
options.text: A doctor can be held liable for negligence if the patient consents to a procedure, regardless of whether they knew the risks involved.

options.label: C
options.text: A defendant (doctor) can avoid liability by proving that the patient voluntarily accepted the risk of injury, with full knowledge of the potential harm.

options.label: D
options.text: A patient who consents to a medical procedure cannot waive their right to compensation, even if the injury was foreseeable.

questions.correct_answer: C. A defendant (doctor) can avoid liability by proving that the patient voluntarily accepted the risk of injury, with full knowledge of the potential harm.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A defendant (doctor) can avoid liability by proving that the patient voluntarily accepted the risk of injury, with full knowledge of the potential harm.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic sinusitis presents with a large, recurrent sinonasal mass that has been causing nasal obstruction, facial pain, and purulent nasal discharge for the past several months. After imaging, the mass is identified as an extensive malignant tumor involving the nasal cavity and the paranasal sinuses, with some extension into the orbit. Due to the size and location of the mass, the surgical team decides to perform a lateral rhinotomy for tumor excision. Which of the following best describes the surgical approach and benefits of Moure’s incision for this procedure?

options.label: A
options.text: Provides direct access to the nasal cavity, sinuses, and orbit through an incision along the upper lip

options.label: B
options.text: Allows exposure of the nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, and anterior skull base with a horizontal incision across the cheek

options.label: C
options.text: Provides a clear view of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses with a vertical incision along the lateral aspect of the nose

options.label: D
options.text: Allows access to the nasal and oral cavities with an incision around the lower jaw and submandibular area

questions.correct_answer: C. Provides a clear view of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses with a vertical incision along the lateral aspect of the nose
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Moure’s incision (lateral rhinotomy) is a vertical incision made along the lateral aspect of the nose and cheek, providing optimal access to the nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, and potentially the orbit for tumor excision or other surgical interventions. This approach is commonly used for sinonasal malignancies that require significant surgical exposure.
  • ➤ Moure’s incision (lateral rhinotomy) is a vertical incision made along the lateral aspect of the nose and cheek, providing optimal access to the nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, and potentially the orbit for tumor excision or other surgical interventions.
  • ➤ This approach is commonly used for sinonasal malignancies that require significant surgical exposure.
